results.title: Grateful angels

results.title: Cardin Street
results.brief_description: A little piece of wood tells a whole story about a house, about home, about friendship. A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallaceâ€™s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, â€˜A Walkabout Filmâ€™, Wallaceâ€™s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called â€˜The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Incâ€™. The â€˜Walkaboutersâ€™ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australiaâ€™. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallaceâ€™s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is about a trip around North Queensland to locations such as Townsville and National Parks. Wallace films the wonderful brolga water birds of the title but also captures the dramatic Wallaman Falls in Girringun Park, which is Australia’s highest permanent single drop waterfall, and the Little Crystal Creek Bridge on Mount Spec Rd in Paluma Range National Park. The bridge and Mt Spec Road are of particular interest as both are listed heritage sites on the Queensland Heritage Register and were constructed during the Great Depression in the 1930s using mostly unskilled labour and with the application of ‘Unemployment Relief Scheme’ funds. Mt Spec Road remains substantially intact throughout the 18km of its length and demonstrates an extensive and now uncommon use of concrete arch culverts, dry stone walling and stone-paved gutters. Also, the very picturesque bridge is the only identified concrete arch bridge dressed with stone remaining in service in Queensland.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Where Brolgas Dance’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:27:00 the ‘Air Cloud’ tour boat moored at a pier
00:00:32:00 looking out from the pier over a lake or river followed by boats sitting on sand and mud when the tide is out and remains of old jettys
00:01:03:00 views of boats moored at jettys and piers
00:02:09:00 sunflowers in the foreground of mountains
00:02:27:00 the ‘Burdekin Bridge’ rail and car bridge in Queensland
00:03:38:00 sugar cane, wetlands and lily pads and roaming cattle
00:04:13:00 a large spider web in the wetlands complete with black spider in the middle
00:04:30:00 driving through Townsville in Queensland, and past the ‘T&G Building’
00:06:13:00 views of brolgas standing in grass and flying overhead
00:07:52:00 signs for ‘Mt Spec National Park’ and ‘Little Crystal Creek’
00:07:59:00 views of the Little Crystal Creek Bridge and the creek itself with its lovely rocky banks
00:08:24:00 a roadside picnic and exploring under the bridge
00:08:54:00 sign for ‘McClelland Bridge’ followed by scenic views of mountains and waterways
00:10:06:00 driving through the rainforest
00:10:48:00 views of the dramatic Wallaman Falls
00:11:01:00 sign for the Falls with facts and information for campers
00:11:34:00 sightseers at a lookout
00:12:03:00 a small modest road bridge
00:12:16:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: Game Masters: Warren Spector interview
results.creator_credit: Dean Robb, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Warren Spector speaks about his career as a videogame designer. Warren refers to his days of playing ‘Dungeons and Dragons’ and the influence this has had on him as a vidoegames designer. A great collector of board games and Disney memorabilia, Warren talks with great passion about the importance of archiving and making games a medium worth recognising.

Warren Spector is a master of role playing game design and has been influenced and inspired by films and literature, such as ‘Blade Runner’ and cyberpunk science fiction, he is best known for creating influential titles such as ‘Deus Ex’ and his most recent release, ‘Disney Epic Mickey’.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: The Village green
results.brief_description:
Vietnamese poet Huong Trieu worked with ACMI to produce a visual treatment of her poetry about village life in Vietnam. This was part of a VicHealth funded initiative.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallaceâ€™s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, â€˜A Walkabout Filmâ€™, Wallaceâ€™s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called â€˜The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Incâ€™. The â€˜Walkaboutersâ€™ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallaceâ€™s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip made by the ‘Walkabouters’ to the Wyperfeld National Park in northwestern Victoria. Wallace as usual focuses on the landscape, flora and fauna and in doing so, captures the arid beauty of the region. A highlight of the film is the usually hard to find malleefowl (or hen), an endangered bird in Victoria that Wallace films in its dry, inland scrub habitat. The malleefowl is a mound builder which, unlike any other birds in Australia, uses its large strong feet to create enormous mounds of soil in which their eggs are incubated, heated by the sun or rotting leaves.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles, ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Wyperfeld’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:33:00 a paddock of grazing sheep
00:00:46:00 a sign for ‘Wyperfeld National Park National Parks Service’ and some wildflowers
00:01:27:00 a malleefowl at work on top of its mound, followed by more wildflowers
00:02:08:00 emus
00:02:28:00 chopping fallen logs
00:02:58:00 a brown beetle
00:03:12:00 walkers on a walking track in the Park
00:03:28:00 a bird in a eucalypt (gumtree)
00:04:01:00 sandy terrain and wildflowers
00:05:34:00 a scary looking banksia plant seed pod close-up followed by more examples of banksia pods
00:06:17:00 the ‘Walkerbouters’ itinerary on a black board, including daily destinations and when to carry lunch
00:06:30:00 views of the landscape around the Park and what is likely to be a variety of blue-tongue lizard
00:08:23:00 the walkers’ campsite and another blackboard itinerary notice
00:09:33:00 the walkers rest on a large, fallen tree log
00:11:05:00 birds flying overhead
00:12:38:00 a particularly wide trunk eucalypt (gumtree) tree in the Park attracts the walkers’ attention
00:13:38:00 sandy dune-like mounds throughout the Park
00:14:18:00 walking under what appears to be old tea tree branches and possibly saltbush among more close-ups of wildflowers

results.title: Dragon's Lair
results.brief_description: Dragonâ€™s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era.

constellations_primary.name: Dragon's Lair
constellations_primary.description: A look at pop-cultural interconnections that spawn from the lair of Don Bluth's arcade classic.

results.description:
Dragonâ€™s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. There are two reasons for that: it was animated by legend Don Bluth, the man behind The Land Before Time (1988); and it used LaserDisc technology, allowing for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games released in 1983.

It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but it maybe shouldâ€™ve been advertised as the hardest videogame. Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragonâ€™s Lairâ€™s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: itâ€™s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).

It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but it maybe shouldâ€™ve been advertised as the hardest videogame. Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragonâ€™s Lairâ€™s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: itâ€™s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).

results.title: Escape from Woomera
results.brief_description: Escape from Woomera is a videogame that asks players to experience Australiaâ€™s draconian immigration policies from the point-of-view of a refugee. By combining game mechanics, art and activism, Escape from Woomera goes beyond the razor wire and detention centre media blackout.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description:
If you thought escaping from Castle Wolfenstein was hard, try Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre…

With a first person, 3D adventure game we invite gamers to assume the character of, and ‘live’ through the experiences of a modern day refugee. The effective media lock-out from immigration detention centres has meant that the whole truth about what goes on behind the razor-wire at Woomera, Baxter, Port Hedland, Maribyrnong and Villawood remains largely a mystery to the Australian public. We want to challenge this by offering the world a glimpse - more than that even: an interactive, immersive experience - of life within the most secretive and controversial places on the Australian political and geographical landscape. In this way, Escape From Woomera will be an engine for mobilising experiences and situations otherwise inaccessible to an nation of disempowered onlookers. It will provide both a portal and a toolkit for reworking and engaging with what is otherwise an entirely mediated current affair.

Lead artist/Environment artist: Stephen Honegger

Level designer: Ian Malcolm

Investigative journalist: Kate Wild

Cutscene artist: Morgan Simpson

Creative director: Katharine Neil

Animators: Andrea Blundell, Chris Markwart

Producers: Justin Halliday, Mark Angeli

Executive producer: Julian Oliver

Admin: Rani Kellock

Programming: Matthew Jones, David Jewsbury, Duncan Murray

Additional programming: Katharine Neil

UI art and website: Monique Jones

QA: Alex McNeilly
